J. Scott Brownlee 's chapbook Highway or Belief was selected by Rachel McKibbens as the winner of the 2013 Button Poetry Prize. Ascension won the 2014 Robert Phillips Poetry Chapbook Prize from Texas Review Press and will be published in May 2015. Requiem for Used Ignition Cap , his first full-length poetry collection, was selected by C. Dale Young as the winner of the 2015 Orison Poetry Prize and will be published in November 2015. Monica McClure 's poetry collection, Tender Data , was published by Birds, LLC in 2015. Robin Coste Lewis 's collection of poems, Voyage of the Sable Venus , is forthcoming from Knopf. Ocean Vuong' s first full-length collection, Night Sky With Exit Wounds , is forthcoming from Copper Canyon Press (2016). He also was the recipient of a Ruth Lilly Poetry Fellowship.  Javier Zamora was the recipient of a 2015 Poetry Fellowship from the National Endowment of the Arts. Bianca Stone 's poetry collection Someone Else's Wedding Vows was published by Tin House/Octopus Books in 2014. Julia Lisella 's newest collection of poems, Always, was published by WordTech editions in 2014. Rachel Basch published her third novel, The Listener , from Pegasus Books in March 2015. Richard Tayson has been awarded a Fellowship from the New York Foundation for the Arts (NYFA) in Non-Fiction Literature. Tsipi Keller 's forthcoming translations include a selected volume of Raquel Chalfi's poems, Reality Crumbs (SUNY Press), and a selected volume of Erez Bitton's poems, You Who Cross My Path (BOA Editions). Both will be published in 2015. Dinika M. Amaral 's story " No Good Deed Unpunished " appeared in the Iowa Review in January 2015 and has been selected for the Tim McGinnis Award . Yoojin Grace Wuertz 's novel recently sold to Random House. The working title is Frog Pond, Shark Pond . Morgan Parker's first collection of poems Other People's Comfort Keeps Me Up At Night    was chosen by Eileen Myles for publication in April 2015 by Switchback   Books. Her second poetry manuscript has also been accepted for   publication in 2016 by Coconut Books.      Scott Bailey's debut collection of poems, Thus Spake Gigolo , is now available, published by NYQ Books.     Solmaz Sharif is the winner of a 2014 Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers Award and Ruth Lilly Poetry Fellowship, and a Stegner Fellowship. Maya Catherine Popa received second place in Narrative Magazine 's sixth annual poetry contest. Rebecca Dinerstein's debut novel, The Sunlit Night , was sold to Bloomsbury at an auction in June 2014.     Amanda Jane McConnon's poem "Life on Earth" was selected by Dorianne Laux for inclusion in Best New Poets 2014 .     Boris Fishman's debut novel, A Replacement Life , was praised in June 2014 in the New York Times Book Review.      Kseniya Melnik's debut story collection Snow in May (Henry Holt, 2014) was one of Amazon's Best Books of the Month and the New Yorker's Books to Watch Out For. Melnik's May 2014 interview with Rachel Martin is available on NPR.      R. A. Villanueva's first book of poems Reliquaria won the Prairie Schooner Book Prize and appeared in fall 2014. Lizzie Harris's debut poetry collection, Stop Wanting , won the Cleveland State University Press Poetry Prize and appeared in spring 2014.      Cathy Linh Che won the 2012 Kundiman Poetry Prize; her first book Split was published by Alice James Books in 2014.     Garth Risk Hallberg's debut novel City on Fire was sold to Knopf, which paid close to $2 million according to the article in The New York Times .                      Description       Feminist study has almost by definition pursued a strong interdisciplinary commitment. This course explores feminist works in different fields and brings them into fuller relationship with each other, with literature, and specifically poetry, as a site in which their intercrossing becomes both accessible and dramatic. A major theme will be definitions of selfhood. Topics will include feminist literary criticism, anthropology, psychology, history, political theory, cultural studies, law; reading theorists such as Harold Bloom, Carole Gilligan, Michel Foucault, Catherine MacKinnon, Jean Bethke Elshtain. Literary figures studied will include Emily Dickinson, Frances Harper, Charlotte Gilman (prose and poetry), Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton, Muriel Rukeyser, Gwendolyn Brooks, Marianne Moore along with other short prose.
